column1: Stephen Blake Jackson, Alyssa Jackson, Tabitha Johnson
Born in Ithaca, New York (Tompkins County) to Christie and Mary Agnes
January, 1937 0 Hoffman. She is their second child (the have a son, Thomas). Virginia grew up in
Virginia grew up in poverty and there are indications that she was physically and
Fall, 1953 16 The Hoffman’s barn burned down. Virginia is suspected of arson.
Virginia marries Dick Coates and they move in with Dick’s parents. After Virginia
Fall, 1954 17 is caught stealing from Dick’s parents, Virginia and Dick move in with Virginia’s
May, 1955 18 Virginia gives birth to her first child, Ronald Albert Coates.
Virginia, Dick, and Ronald move into a house of their own in Newfield, NY.
Virginia has many sexual affairs and continues to steal.
1956 Virginia gives birth to her second child,. Jimmy.
After a fire in their rented home, The Coates’ are asked to find a new place to live
and move back in with her parents. Dick suspects Virginia set the fire.
07-03-1959 21 Virginia is arrested for forging $195 in checks.
10-05-1959 22 Virginia pleads guilty and is placed on two years of probation.
Fall, 1961 24 Virginia’s house catches on fire.
Virginia and Dick separate. Virginia takes the two boys and they move back with
The Hoffman’s house where Virginia is living in Ithaca, NY, catches on fire.
March, 1967 30 Virginia falls from a second-story window and hits her head.  She is hospitalized for
Virginia’s daughter, Cynthia Elaine Coates, is born in Palo Alto, California (Source:
02-25-1971 34 Virginia’ and Dick’s divorce becomes official.
06-05-1971 35 Virginia marries Sylvester “Bud” Rearden in Santa Clara County, California

column3: (Source: California Marriage Index, 1960-1985). Bud is in the Navy and has threesons: Kenneth, Sylvester, and Butch.
Virginia and Bud move to Louisville when Bud is transferred. They move into ahouse in Fairdale, Kentucky.
First alleged victim, daughter Cynthia Elaine Coats (WF, 3), was found hanging in aLouisville, Kentucky barn by McGinnis.
Cynthia Coats is buried in Resthaven Memorial Park
Virginia’s second husband, Sylvester “Bud” Rearden (WM, 36), dies in Louisville,KY. Although he died from cancer, many speculate that Virginia caused him to dieearlier than he would have.
Virginia moves from Kentucky to California.
Virginia marries Billie Joe “B.J.” McGinnis at the Wedding Bells Chapel in CarsonCity, Nevada. This was his fifth marriage and Virginia’s third marriage.
The house in Palo Alto, CA, where Virginia and her mother are living, catches fireand the insurance company decides to rebuild it rather than paying a claim.
The house catches on fire again and burns to the ground. The fire inspectors suspectarson but the insurance company pays Virginia and her mother $122,255.
Virginia’s mother, Mary Agnes Hoffman (WF, 74), dies of a heart attack in ChulaVista, California.
Virginia McGinnis took out a $35,000 life insurance policy on Deana Wild.

Last Victim, Deanna Wild (WF, 20), was found dead in Big Sur, California. Policeeventually suspect that Virginia and B.J. McGinnis drove Deanna from San Diegoand then pushed her over a cliff in Big Sur,
Virginia and B.J. get divorced.
Virginia is now living in Pittsburg, California
Virginia is arrested at her home in Pittsburg, California.
Murder charges were filed against McGinnis by San Diego Prosecutor’s Office.
Jury selection begins in Virginia’s trial for the murder of Deanna Wild,
Accomplice and third husband, Billie Joe McGinnis (WM, 52), dies of AIDS.
Virginia McGinnis is held in Las Colinas Jail in Santee, California.
Jury selection ends and the trial begins.
The jurors are flown from San Diego to Monterey to view the crime scene.
The jurors begin deliberation
The jury delivers a verdict of, “Guilty of murder in the first degree”.
Virginia was sentenced to life without parole for the murder of Deana HubbardWild.

Retrieved fromhttp://www.deseretnews.com/article/218156/KILLER-FEELS-NO-GUILT.html?pg=allSimon, R. I. (2008). Bad Men Do What Good Men Dream (pp. 50-51). Our group did an extensive search through books, online publications,LexisNexis, newspapers, Ancestory.com, and received help from the Reference Desk in the Library. This is all theinformation we could gather on Virginia McGinnis.  She is not a very well-known serial killer; however, her story isinteresting nonetheless. We wish we could find more on her, but the information out there is limited.  The book “DeathBenefit” was more of a narrative of the lawyer who got involved in Deanna Wild’s death and uncovered the truth abouther murder. The other victims’ information was much harder to find and background information on McGinnis as well.
